SENT.plain: A 79-year old man noticed paresthesia in all 4 limbs, quadriplegia and dysarthria, and then developed respiratory arrest requiring mechanical ventilation
After level of consciousness was improved, vertical gaze palsy, left hemifacial palsy (central type) and quadriplegia were noted
Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) on day 9 revealed bilateral upper medial medullary infarction

In general, the vertical gaze center is thought to be present in the midbrain, including the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus, posterior commissure and interstitial nucleus of Cajal
Few reports have described vertical gaze palsy due to medullary lesions
The upper medial medullary lesions, particularly the paramedian tract in the medulla, may have been responsible for vertical gaze palsy in this patient
